block.p: Rogue Software Program Wreaks Havoc Worldwide A rogue software program, borne by an e-mail message proclaiming ''I love you,'' wreaked havoc around the world, jamming and crashing e-mail systems and destroying data on hundreds of thousands of computers.

To defend themselves, thousands of corporations unhooked their computer systems from the Internet and began the slow process of purging the program internally. The program also hit government agencies, including the White House, the Pentagon, Congress and the British House of Commons. [Page A1.]

J. C. Penney's Chief to Step Down James E. Oesterreicher, 58, the chairman and chief executive of the troubled retailer J. C. Penney, announced his intention to retire almost a year sooner than expected. In his three-year tenure, Mr. Oesterreicher had been unable to lift slumping sales and a sagging share price despite implementing many changes. No successor was named. [C2.]

Blue Chips Fall Ahead of Jobs Report Blue-chip stocks ended lower ahead of today's April unemployment report, which is expected to provide clues about how much further the Federal Reserve will increase interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 67.64 points, or 0.65 percent, to 10,412.49. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5.72 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,409.38. The Nasdaq composite index finished up 12.93 points, or 0.35 percent, at 3,720.24. [C9.]

House Passes Trade Legislation The House of Representatives approved compromise legislation that would extend billions of dollars in new trade privileges to Africa, the Caribbean and Central America. The 309 to 110 vote was seen as a major trade-policy victory for President Clinton. The Senate is expected to approve the measure next week. [A1.]

Cable and Wireless Sets Vote on Bid Pacific Century Cyberworks moved a step closer to sealing its audacious bid for Hong Kong's main telephone company, as the board of Cable and Wireless HKT approved the filing of a takeover document to be voted on by shareholders next month. [C4.]

Seagram Earnings Beat Forecast Seagram, the Canadian media and beverage company, posted a wider loss in its third fiscal quarter but still beat analysts' expectations. The owner of the Universal movie and music studios lost $265 million, or 61 cents. Analysts had expected a loss of 66 cents. Shares of Seagram rose $1.125, to $53.4375. [C3.]

Cable Viewers May Go to Satellite About 25,000 Time Warner subscribers, who were blocked from cable television earlier this week, have asked for coupons that entitle them to receive free satellite dishes. [C6.]

Retail Sales Fall Short in April Hit by unusually cold spring weather, many of the nation's merchants reported that sales fell short of their goals in April. Sales in stores open at least a year, a key industry measurement, jumped 7.6 percent last month, which included Easter. [C2.]

U.S. Indicts 17 for Software Theft Seventeen people, including former and current employees of Intel and Microsoft, were indicted for copyright infringement in the largest ever theft case involving intellectual property and the Internet, the Justice Department said. The department accused them of creating a private library of more than 5,000 stolen programs available on the Internet. [C5.]
